Posts.Content: sstw0324 wrote: My mother is 82 and was diagnosed with BC 2 weeks ago - and we were told today that its at least S3 - possibly S4.  She is starting chemo a week from tomorrow - port being inserted on Friday of this week.  My mom is not the typical 82 year old - she's always been so healthy and young for her age - this has come out of the blue and has my head absolutely spinning.  I am the youngest of 4 and her only daughter, and we are extremely close - and I'm having trouble concentrating on anything other than her.  Work is an absolute joke - which is not a great thing when you're in sales and on 100% commission!!  My mom is my rock and I feel like someone has pulled the rug from under me.  Instead of a 50 year old woman, I find myself feeling like a 6 year old little girl who "wants her mommy!"  The chemo reg. she will be on is taxotere & carboplatin - any insight into that is welcome. My 2 brothers and 2 sisters-in-law and I are thinking that once she starts the chemo, that we should take shifts so that she is not alone - at least though the first cyle - to see how she reacts and can handle the chemo and any of its side effects.  Is this smart - overkill - or what?  She lives alone (our father died 26 years ago) and she's lived alone since that time and is fiercely independent - and we don't want to take that away from her, but don't want her to get sick from the chemo and be alone.....ideas, thoughts?????   I know everyone is different, but is there a day that's usually worse than others?  She'll be on a once a week regimine, 3 weeks on and 1 off for 4 rounds.  Thanks for any insight. Sharon My mother was diagnosed in July 2010 with Stage IV BC and is a TN. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Questons on helping my mom - Please send your thoughts!!!! sstw0324 Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 07:52PM sstw0324 wrote: My mom's breast cancer is rare - its actually squamous carcinoma (usually known more for skin cancer) and in the case of breast cancer is very aggressive - and lymph nodes are involved, as well as suspicous areas in other parts (abdomen, chest) - hence the rush to start chemo to stop the spread followed by surgery.  We have not gotten a second opinion - the oncologist came very highly recommended - and everything that he has told us so far has seemed very logical and seemed to "gel" with everything that I've read so far on my own.  He's very receptive to questions, suggestions, etc.  At this point, my mom trusts and likes him - and he spends as much time with her as she wants answering all of her (and my) questions, so she has no desire to seek another opinion - and he has told us that he believes that because she is in such good shape that with this regimine, he expects her to beat this.
